But First . . . . .

HIGHLIGHTS

01.

Problem
Ideation.

Problem ideation transforms challenges into solutions through research and structured framing. It starts by identifying a relevant, solvable, and ethical problem, crafting a focused problem statement, and using research to refine it. The "How Might We" framework breaks down the problem into actionable steps, ensuring solutions are practical, scalable, and impactful. Collaboration ensures alignment and solutions backed by research insights.

02.

Solution
Ideation.

The "Solution Ideation" process emphasizes a problem-solution approach to innovation. Strong research validates ideas and refines problem statements. Use pilot studies and diverse sources to support specific issues. The solution model canvas defines the target user, offering, technology, and expected outcomes. Finalize research-backed problem statements and document thoroughly to strengthen your pitch.

03.

Pitching

The "Pitching" phase focuses on developing effective pitching and presentation techniques for innovation. Key components include storytelling to create memorable narratives, structuring the pitch with clear problem and solution slides, and honing presentation skills by limiting text and ensuring readability. A solid pitch should start with a strong title, introduce relatable characters, and emphasize the impact of the problem. After the pitch, document your process, refine your solution based on feedback, and prepare through rehearsals.

GEMS

"Facts are 20x more likely to be remembered if they are part of a story."

"Never tell a point without a story, never tell a story without a point."
